commit_message:
Adding VRRP fall and rise count cfg options

Change-Id: Ifa545158779781d0ed907aceb5958f4de40767ce
Closes-Bug: #1892200
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/72/760372/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- features: - | New config options ``ha_vrrp_health_check_fall`` and ``ha_vrrp_health_check_rise`` are added. These control the number of times checks must fail or succeed for the VRRP state to change to unhealthy or healthy. The default for both of these options is the previously hard coded count of ``2``.

subject: RFC: Update the install documents for cells and less distro specific
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-11-19 17:14:31.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/d03b80a9030ed8fdb62ba0aadbd5530cb3fb05cb', 'message': "RFC: Update the install documents for cells and less distro specific

Recent discussions with deployment tool authors around how services
get default configurations has led to the realization that we need
some advice in our docs about which services get which config. The
install docs actually kinda already have that, although it's a bit
crufty. There is clearly no indication of what needs to happen for
multi-cell deployments, although controllers and computes are called
out separately, and the database config is excluded from the latter,
as needed.

This attempts to freshen some of those docs with mentions about services
potentially requiring different configs, along with which services
need what. It also puts some notes in place about compute not having
database access.

Finally, while working on this, I realized that we have three copies
of each controller/compute install doc, but the diff between them is
very small. It's clear that some docs have been updated over the
years and some have not (for example, the RedHat docs still
indicate that nova-api things should be configured on the compute nodes)
and the Ubuntu docs have not been updated for the systemd transisiton.

So, this removes the three, replaced with just the ubuntu one (which
appears to be the most up-to-date from a nova perspective). Some
distro-specific items are called out in the doc (like service names),
but I think in general, we should not try to document all the distro-
specific details, especially since that is not likely to age well
(re: the systemd transition from sixish years ago).

FIXME: This needs to de-ubuntu the filename, as well as fix up some
of the links that point to the distro-specific versions. I'm putting
this up as an RFC of sorts before I go to all that trouble.

Change-Id: Ic10f68e8c2b4691f5457ac786f48082dc7f087fd
Related-Bug: #1904179

commit_message:
RFC: Update the install documents for cells and less distro specific

Recent discussions with deployment tool authors around how services
get default configurations has led to the realization that we need
some advice in our docs about which services get which config. The
install docs actually kinda already have that, although it's a bit
crufty. There is clearly no indication of what needs to happen for
multi-cell deployments, although controllers and computes are called
out separately, and the database config is excluded from the latter,
as needed.

This attempts to freshen some of those docs with mentions about services
potentially requiring different configs, along with which services
need what. It also puts some notes in place about compute not having
database access.

Finally, while working on this, I realized that we have three copies
of each controller/compute install doc, but the diff between them is
very small. It's clear that some docs have been updated over the
years and some have not (for example, the RedHat docs still
indicate that nova-api things should be configured on the compute nodes)
and the Ubuntu docs have not been updated for the systemd transisiton.

So, this removes the three, replaced with just the ubuntu one (which
appears to be the most up-to-date from a nova perspective). Some
distro-specific items are called out in the doc (like service names),
but I think in general, we should not try to document all the distro-
specific details, especially since that is not likely to age well
(re: the systemd transition from sixish years ago).

FIXME: This needs to de-ubuntu the filename, as well as fix up some
of the links that point to the distro-specific versions. I'm putting
this up as an RFC of sorts before I go to all that trouble.

Change-Id: Ic10f68e8c2b4691f5457ac786f48082dc7f087fd
Related-Bug: #1904179
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/12/763412/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # mysql -u root -p The mechanism and package names will vary based on the distro you are using. Check with your vendor for specifics, or try one of the flavors available below. For Debian or Ubuntu: # apt-get install nova-api nova-conductor nova-novncproxy nova-scheduler For Redhat-based distros, like RDO: .. code-block:: console # dnf install openstack-nova-api openstack-nova-conductor openstack-nova-vncproxy openstack-nova-scheduler #. Configure the controller services. .. note:: Depending on the cell architecture you have chosen, it may be possible to have all the services on the controller share the same config file. If you are not running a multi-cell architecture, or have separate nodes for the api services and the cell conductors, then the services on each can use a common config file. However, if you mix the roles on a single machine, you should create multiple config files and arrange for each service to run with the appropriate config. Edit the ``/etc/nova/nova.conf`` file and complete the following actions: In a single-cell deployment, all controller services need both sets of database credentials. In a multi-cell deployment, the api, scheduler, and superconductor services need both sets, and should have their ``[database]/connection`` set to the ``cell0`` database. Cell conductors should have theirs set to the appropriate cell database name. The metadata api service, if running in one-per-cell mode should not have the ``[api_database]/connection`` specified, and the ``[database]/connection`` should point to the appropriate cell database. * Restart the Compute services. For Debian or Ubuntu: # systemctl restart nova-api # systemctl restart nova-scheduler # systemctl restart nova-conductor # systemctl restart nova-novncproxy For Redhat-based distros, like RDO: .. code-block:: console # systemctl restart openstack-nova-api # systemctl restart openstack-nova-scheduler # systemctl restart openstack-nova-conductor # systemctl restart openstack-nova-novncproxy
deleted_lines: # mysql # apt install nova-api nova-conductor nova-novncproxy nova-scheduler #. Edit the ``/etc/nova/nova.conf`` file and complete the following actions:* Restart the Compute services: # service nova-api restart # service nova-scheduler restart # service nova-conductor restart # service nova-novncproxy restart

commit_message:
Hello Venus

This project provide an OpenStack Log Management Service.

Change-Id: I3fd77e52240eb348b09c8c22f7aa20a9234ecd93
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/venus refs/changes/25/763525/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Hello Venus =========== An OpenStack Log Management Service. About Venus ----------- In light of the problems and needs of retrieval, storage and analysis etc. of logs on the OpenStack platform, we developed the OpenStack log management module Venus. This project can provide a one-stop solution to log collection, cleaning, indexing, analysis, alarm, visualization, report generation and other needs, which involves helping operator or maintainer to quickly solve retrieve problems, grasp the operational health of the platform, and improve the level of platform management. Additionally, this project plans to use machine learning algorithms to quickly locate IT failures and root causes, and improve operation and maintenance efficiency.

commit_message:
Add os-volume_attachments reference docs

This change adds a simple sequence diagram showing the flow of a volume
attachment between the various services, using the libvirt driver as an
example virt driver.

Change-Id: I631ac9de3d48aa0ad849f6615d0ad2052cb63e80

commit_message:
Use TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE

UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE is old name and deprecated
-https://zuul-ci.org/docs/zuul-jobs/python-roles.html#rolevar-tox.tox_constraints_file
This allows to use lower-constraints file as more
readable way instead of UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE=<lower-constraints file>.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/722814/

Change-Id: Ie06d4e049e5e82fc0f75b8f3791b0b39594782b3
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-ken refs/changes/13/760713/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: -c{env:TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://releases.openstack.org/constraints/upper/master}

commit_message:
Reproduce bug 1897528

The nova-compute fails to start if the hypervisor has PCI addresses
32bit domain.

Change-Id: I48dcb7faa17fe9f8346445a1746cff5845baf358
Related-Bug: #1897528
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/96/756696/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from nova import exception def test_update_devices_from_hypervisor_resources_32bit_domain(self): self.flags( group='pci', passthrough_whitelist=[ '{"product_id":"2032", "vendor_id":"8086"}']) # There are systems where 32 bit PCI domain is used. See bug 1897528 # for example. While nova (and qemu) does not support assigning such # devices but the existence of such device in the system should not # lead to an error. fake_pci = { 'compute_node_id': 1, 'address': '10000:00:02.0', 'product_id': '2032', 'vendor_id': '8086', 'request_id': None, 'status': fields.PciDeviceStatus.AVAILABLE, 'dev_type': fields.PciDeviceType.STANDARD, 'parent_addr': None, 'numa_node': 0} fake_pci_devs = [fake_pci] fake_pci_devs_json = jsonutils.dumps(fake_pci_devs) tracker = manager.PciDevTracker(self.fake_context) # We expect that the device with 32bit PCI domain is ignored # tracker.update_devices_from_hypervisor_resources(fake_pci_devs_json) # self.assertEqual(0, len(tracker.pci_devs)) # # This is the bug 1897528 ex = self.assertRaises( exception.PciConfigInvalidWhitelist, tracker.update_devices_from_hypervisor_resources, fake_pci_devs_json) self.assertEqual( 'Invalid PCI devices Whitelist config: property domain (10000) is ' 'greater than the maximum allowable value (FFFF).', str(ex))

commit_message:
Update TOX/UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/ussuri

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/ussuri branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I0271468a19690503d2b91d20893dfaeb932d7348
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/os-ken refs/changes/31/719231/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Add a test for Controller failover

- Check who is the leader
- Block the node that hosts the leader from accessing k8s API
- Check that that a new leader was chosen

Change-Id: I8471a00a37eb3dd93d912435fcff514d5d32df09
Depends-On: Iabebf14b64b9306e4ebc6ff827151feee27e5c11

added_lines: CONTROLLER_KEEPALIVE_TIME = 5 TRANSITION_TIMEOUT = 30 TRANSITION_INTERVAL = 5 def was_leader_changed(self): annotation = self.get_kuryr_leader_annotation() self.assertIsNotNone(annotation) leader = annotation['holderIdentity'] return leader != self.original_leader def test_service_controller_transition(self): controller_deployment = ( self.k8s_client.AppsV1Api().read_namespaced_deployment( CONF.kuryr_kubernetes.controller_deployment_name, CONF.kuryr_kubernetes.kube_system_namespace)) # On cleanup scale to original number of replicas self.addCleanup(self.scale_controller_deployment, controller_deployment.spec.replicas) # Scale to 2 replicas self.scale_controller_deployment(2) # Get current leader annotation annotation = self.get_kuryr_leader_annotation() self.assertIsNotNone(annotation) self.original_leader = annotation['holderIdentity'] kuryr_pod_name = self.get_kuryr_controller_pod(self.original_leader) # Get the non leader IP nodes = self.get_controller_nodes_names() - set([self.original_leader]) non_leader_ip = self.get_node_ip(nodes.pop()) self.assertIsNotNone(non_leader_ip) # Get the current security group of the opesnhift LoadBalancer api_service_ip = self.get_service_ip('kubernetes') ports = self.admin_manager.ports_client.list_ports() api_security_group_id = [port['security_groups'][0] for port in ports['ports'] if port['fixed_ips'][0]['ip_address'] == api_service_ip][0] # Block connectivity of the openshift LB from the exisisting controller node original_sg_rules = self.admin_manager.security_group_rules_client.list_security_group_rules(security_group_id=api_security_group_id)['security_group_rules'] self.addCleanup(self.restore_security_group_rules, api_security_group_id, original_sg_rules) sg_rules_to_remove = [rule['id'] for rule in original_sg_rules if rule['port_range_max'] == 443] for rule_id in sg_rules_to_remove: self.admin_manager.security_group_rules_client.delete_security_group_rule(rule_id) self.admin_manager.security_group_rules_client.create_security_group_rule( security_group_id=api_security_group_id, port_range_min='443', port_range_max='443', remote_ip_prefix=non_leader_ip, direction='ingress',protocol='tcp') annotation = self.get_kuryr_leader_annotation() test_utils.call_until_true(self.was_leader_changed, TRANSITION_TIMEOUT , TRANSITION_INTERVAL) # Create a new service and check connectivity # Check connectivity to an existing service

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2020-09-17 15:00:15.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/functional/regressions/test_bug_1895696.py', 'nova/compute/api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/297435ad9ed8b8cfed98617f5ec6774a17cb28ef', 'message': "compute: Skip cinder_encryption_key_id check when booting from volume

Idf84ccff254d26fa13473fe9741ddac21cbcf321 added this check in order for
Nova to avoid booting encrypted images created by Cinder as there is
currently no support for using such images (rotating keys etc).

The check however missed the slightly convoluted use case where this
image property is found against a volume after the volume in question is
created using an encrypted image created by cinder from an encrypted
volume. In other words:

- Cinder creates an encrypted volume A
- Glance creates an encrypted image A from volume A
- Cinder creates an encrypted volume B from image A
- Nova attempts to boot an instance using volume B

Note that Nova may request the creation of volume B or a user could also
do this directly through Cinder.

As such this change simply ensures that the instance isn't booting from
a volume when preforming the check as it is only valid when booting from
an image.

Closes-Bug: #1895696
Change-Id: Ic92cab7362fa25050e5bbef5c3e360108365b5c7
(cherry picked from commit f9b67893acf94c06fd41be36b80b99788dc77e48)
"}]
commit_message:
compute: Skip cinder_encryption_key_id check when booting from volume

Idf84ccff254d26fa13473fe9741ddac21cbcf321 added this check in order for
Nova to avoid booting encrypted images created by Cinder as there is
currently no support for using such images (rotating keys etc).

The check however missed the slightly convoluted use case where this
image property is found against a volume after the volume in question is
created using an encrypted image created by cinder from an encrypted
volume. In other words:

- Cinder creates an encrypted volume A
- Glance creates an encrypted image A from volume A
- Cinder creates an encrypted volume B from image A
- Nova attempts to boot an instance using volume B

Note that Nova may request the creation of volume B or a user could also
do this directly through Cinder.

As such this change simply ensures that the instance isn't booting from
a volume when preforming the check as it is only valid when booting from
an image.

Closes-Bug: #1895696
Change-Id: Ic92cab7362fa25050e5bbef5c3e360108365b5c7
(cherry picked from commit f9b67893acf94c06fd41be36b80b99788dc77e48)
